title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Argentina’s move to woo Trump has derailed South America’s largest radio telescope
items.description: U.S.-Chinese tensions have left nearly complete observatory in limbo, jeopardizing research into pulsars and other celestial objects

items.title: Congress close to passing law that would freeze out certain Chinese biotechs
items.description: Latest version of Biosecure Act could raise costs for academic biology labs in an effort to prevent theft of Americans’ health data

items.title: Man’s pig kidney fails just shy of setting record
items.description: The xenotransplant, from a gene-edited pig, had survived for nearly 9 months in Tim Andrews

items.title: Justice Department unexpectedly drops fraud case against Alzheimer’s scientist
items.description: Decision comes after disclosure of university letter concluding Hoau-Yan Wang did not engage in misconduct

items.title: Rats filmed snatching bats from air for first time
items.description: Stunning hunting behaviour captured in German cave

items.title: Ambient noise can track dangerous ocean acidification
items.description: Acoustic technique could make it easier to monitor threat to marine life stemming from rising carbon emissions

items.title: How NSF hopes to keep Antarctic scientists afloat without an icebreaker
items.description: Ending Palmer lease is one of many belt-tightening moves amid budget uncertainty

items.title: At futuristic meeting, AIs took the lead in producing and reviewing all the studies
items.description: Organizers aim to tune AI to help accelerate science

items.title: Can the Deadliest Catch crab fishery survive warming seas?
items.description: After a brutal heat wave, scientists race to predict how Bering Sea snow crabs will cope with climate change

items.title: University of California faculty push back against Big Brother cybersecurity mandate
items.description: School officials defend software as bulwark against ransomware, but professors fear potential surveillance of their devices
